CLEANING & RUG REPAIR

  • services
  • DESIGN CONSULTING
  • CLEANING & REPAIR

WONDERS
OF WOOL

Quality rugs are generally made of wool, an extremely durable fiber that consistently outperforms other materials. It is more resilient to stains, is less absorbent, cleans better and stays clean longer.

Rotation
& RENEWAL

To ensure even wear, your rug should be rotated every six months to two years, depending on traffic and location.

Padding

A quality pad under your rug helps protect it from dirt, slippage, and wear on the bottom of the rug, which is actually more important to protect as it is the source of the knots. We carry two different styles of pad and can suggest the appropriate one for your rug and home and have one custom cut to your size.

We pride ourselves on carrying some of the finest quality rugs on the market. Most of them will last generations when cared for properly. Here are some basic guidelines and advice to protect and care for you heirloom quality investment. In addition to everyday care, the occasional professional cleaning will enhance your rugs, bringing out the richness of color and the softness of the wool. Depending on the amount of traffic on a rug, a professional cleaning is recommended every one to three years. WARNING: no not take a fine rug to an everyday carpet cleaner, as it could result in fading or damage to the rug. Our rug cleaners deal exclusively with oriental rugs and have for generations.

CONTACT US FOR MORE ASSISTANCE

Repair and Resttoration

Old and antique rugs sometimes need to be restored, and just about any damage can be fixed by the right professionals. For these matters it is imperative to seek out experienced hands. The cleaners/repairmen we use are among the best, so feel free to work through us.

DAILY MAINTANCE

When spills occur, dilute with plenty of water. Next, blot from the edge of the spill toward the center. Avoid rubbing the area. For solid spills, take a spoon and carefully scoop up the material. It is always best to attack the spill immediately. It is ok to use a very mild diluted detergent (no bleaches or alkalis) or diluted white vinegar on wool, but be careful and always follow up with water.
